title: 105_hr3551
content: The "Identity Piracy Act of 1998" may be cited as the official title of this Act. It addresses identity theft and deceptive assumption. The "Identity Piracy Act of 1998" addresses identity theft and deceptive assumption by prohibiting the obtaining, transferring, possessing, or using of personal identifiers or identification devices with intent to deceive or defraud. The "Identity Piracy Act of 1998" punishes those involved in conspiracy to commit identity theft with fines or imprisonment for up to 20 years. Restitution may also be ordered by the court for convicted offenders. The court may order restitution for victims of identity theft, including payment for costs incurred in clearing credit history. The Secret Service has investigative authority for offenses under this section, subject to an agreement between the Treasury Secretary and the Attorney General. Definitions for 'means of identification' and 'personal identifier' are provided in this section. The curr_chunk defines various terms related to identity theft, including 'means of identification' and 'personal information or data'. It includes unique identifiers like biometric data, electronic identification numbers, and other means of identification not lawfully issued to the user. The curr_chunk amends Section 80302(a) of title 49, United States Code, to include items involved in identity theft violations as seizure and forfeiture items. This includes false identification documents, document-making implements, counterfeit access devices, and device-making equipment. The curr_chunk discusses the annual reporting requirements for identity theft offenses under section 1036 of title 18, United States Code. The Secretary of the Treasury is mandated to collect and maintain information on identity fraud investigations, prosecutions, convictions, and information provided by State and local law enforcement agencies. The Secretary of the Treasury, in conjunction with the Federal Trade Commission, must conduct a study on identity fraud within a year of this Act's enactment. The study will focus on the extent, nature, and causes of identity fraud, as well as threats to financial institutions, payment systems, and consumer safety. Legislative recommendations to address these issues will be submitted to Congress.
